column3: a result that is difficult to square with the express congressional purpose of ensuring tax parity between corporations that operate through foreign subsidiaries and those that operate through foreign branches. column5: Exemption 7(A) of the FOIA
column6: which exempts from disclosure ""records or information compiled for law enforcement purposes"" under certain circumstances.  Two days later
column7: the requested records were transferred to petitioner Federal Bureau of Investigation
column8: which denied respondent's renewed FOIA request
column9: citing Exemption 7(A).  Respondent sought review in the District Court
column10: which ruled that petitioners were not required to turn over any of the documents and dismissed the complaint
column11: stating that disclosure would jeopardize the grand jury proceeding.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column12: ruling that the Government may not invoke Exemption 7(A) to protect from disclosure materials that were not investigatory records when originally collected
column13: but have since acquired investigative significance.

column1: Held:  Exemption 7(A) may be invoked to prevent the disclosure of documents not originally created for
column2: but later gathered for
column3: law enforcement purposes.  The plain words of the statute contain no requirement that compilation be effected at a specific time

column5: since ""compiled"" naturally refers to the process of gathering at one time records and information that were generated on an earlier occasion
column6: and for a different purpose.  This reading of the statute recognizes the balance struck by Congress between the public's interest in greater access to information and the Government's need to protect certain kinds of information from disclosure
column7: and is supported by the FOIA's legislative history.  Pp.  493 U. S. 153-158.

|493 u.s. 67|Breininger v. Sheet Metal Workers International
Pursuant to a multi-employer collective bargaining agreement
column2: respondent union operates a hiring hall through which it refers both members and nonmembers for work at the request of employers.  The hiring hall is ""nonexclusive
column3: in that workers are free to seek employment through other means
column4: and employers are not restricted to hiring persons recommended by the union.  Petitioner
column5: a member of the union
column6: filed suit alleging that respondent:  (1) violated  101(a)(5) and 609 of the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 (LMRDA) -- which forbid a union to ""fine
column7: suspend
column8: expe[l] or otherwise discipline"" a member for exercising LMRDA-secured rights -- by refusing to refer him through the hiring hall as a result of his political opposition to respondent's leadership; and (2) breached its duty of fair representation under the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) by discriminating against him in respect to such referrals.  The District Court dismissed the suit on the ground that discrimination in hiring hall referrals constitutes an unfair labor practice subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB or Board).  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column9: ruling that fair representation claims must be brought before the Board
column10: and that petitioner had failed to state a claim under the LMRDA.

column1: 1. The District Court did not lack jurisdiction over petitioner's fair representation suit.  Pp.  493 U. S. 73-90.

(a) The NLRB does not have exclusive jurisdiction over a union member's claim that his union breached its duty of fair representation by discriminating against him in job referrals made by the union hiring hall.  The fact that the alleged violation of respondent's duty of fair representation might also be an unfair labor practice
column2: over which state and federal courts lack jurisdiction under San Diego Building Trades Council v. Garmon
column5: did not deprive the District Court of jurisdiction over petitioner's fair representation claim
column6: since Vaca v. Sipes
column8: held that Garmon's preemption rule does not extend to suits alleging such claims.  No exception to the Vaca rule can be created for fair representation complaints arising out of the operation of hiring

column1: halls on the ground that the NLRB has developed substantial expertise in dealing with hiring hall policies.  Such a rule would remove an unacceptably large number of fair representation claims from federal courts
column2: since the NLRB has developed an unfair labor practice jurisprudence in many areas traditionally encompassed by the duty of fair representation.  Decisions of this Court containing language recognizing the need for a single expert federal agency to adjudicate difficult hiring hall problems are distinguished
column3: since those cases focused on whether exclusive hiring halls had encouraged union membership impermissibly as forbidden by the NLRA
column4: rather than on whether unions have administered properly out-of-work lists as required by their duty of fair representation.  Also distinguished are the Court's decisions holding that state court hiring hall suits are preempted by NLRB jurisdiction
column5: since state law claims frequently involve tort
column6: contract
column7: and other substantive areas of law that have developed independently of federal labor law

Texas law provides that any party dissatisfied with a State Industrial Accident Board workers' compensation ruling may bring a civil suit to set the decision aside.  The court determines such cases de novo
column2: and the party seeking compensation bears the burden of proof regardless of which party prevailed before the board.  Pursuant to Texas law
column3: respondent Brewer
column4: a Texas citizen employed by a Texas corporation
column5: filed a workers' compensation claim with the board against the employer's insurer
column6: petitioner here
column7: an Illinois corporation with its principal place of business in that State.  After the board awarded Brewer compensation
column8: petitioner filed an action in Federal District Court
column9: invoking the court's diversity jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C.  1332.  The court dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.  Holding that Fifth Circuit precedent
column10: Campbell v. Insurance Co. of North America
column12: required it to apply the direct action proviso of  1332(c) -- which states that

column1: in any direct action against the insurer of a policy . . . of liability insurance . . such insurer shall be deemed a citizen of the State of which the insured is a citizen. . . .""
-- the court attributed the employer's Texas citizenship to petitioner
column2: thus eliminating diversity between petitioner and Brewer.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The direct action proviso does not apply to actions brought in federal court by an insurer.  The proviso's language unambiguously applies only to actions against insurers and does not mention actions by insurers.  This reading is reinforced by the proviso's legislative history.  Campbell's analysis -- that an action such as petitioner's is an action against an insurer
column2: since the entire process is initiated by an employee's claim to the board
column3: since the employee has the burden of proof at the trial
column4: and since the insurer's action is merely an ""appeal"" of the board's ruling -- is rejected.  Although the employee retains some of the characteristics of a plaintiff at trial
column5: the action is commenced when the insurer files the complaint in court
column6: not when the employee files his claim with the board.  Moreover
column7: the board's award is vacated once the court acquires jurisdiction over the suit.  The seeming incongruity Congress created by retaining diversity jurisdiction over actions brought by out-of-state insurers while withdrawing removal jurisdiction when it eliminated diversity

column1: jurisdiction in actions brought against them is insufficient to persuade this Court to extend the scope of the proviso's precise wording.  Cf. Horton v. Liberty Mutual Ins. Co.

column2: reversed and remanded.

Respondent moved for summary judgment on the ground that the District Court lacked jurisdiction because petitioners had failed to notify the State of Oregon and the EPA as required by  6972(b).  Petitioners then notified the state and federal agencies of the suit.  The District Court denied respondent's motion on the ground that petitioners satisfied RCRA's notice requirement by notifying these agencies and

column1: Held:  Where a party suing under RCRA's citizen suit provision fails to meet the notice and 60-day delay requirements of  6972(b)
column2: the action must be dismissed as barred by the terms of the statute.  Pp.  493 U. S. 25-33.

column1: (a) The plain language of the statute establishes that compliance with the 60-day notice provision is a mandatory
column2: not optional
column3: condition precedent for suit
column4: and may not be disregarded at a court's discretion.  Actions commenced prior to 60 days after notice are ""prohibited"" under  6972(b)
column5: and
column6: because this language is expressly incorporated by reference into  6972(a)
column7: it acts as a specific limitation on a citizen's right to bring suit.  Pp.  493 U. S. 25-26.

column1: (b) None of petitioners' arguments for giving the statute a flexible or pragmatic construction require this Court to disregard the statute's plain language.  The argument that the notice requirement should be deemed

satisfied if a suit commenced without proper notice is stayed until 60 days after notice has been given is rejected.  Whether or not a stay is in fact the functional equivalent of precommencement delay
column2: staying judicial action once the suit has been filed does not honor  6972(b)'s prohibition on the filing of a complaint before the 60-day notice requirement is fulfilled.  Although Congress excepted parties from complying with a delay requirement elsewhere in RCRA
column3: it did not do so in petitioners' situation
column4: and this Court may not create such an exception where Congress has declined to do so.  The contention that the 60-day notice provision is subject to equitable modification and cure is also unavailing.  The equities do not weigh in favor of modifying statutory requirements when the procedural default is caused by petitioners' failure to take the minimal steps necessary to preserve their claims.  Nor can petitioners' failure be excused on the ground that it would be unfair to hold them
column5: as laypersons
column6: to strict compliance with the statute
column7: since this suit
column8: like RCRA citizen suits generally
column9: was filed by a trained lawyer.  Zipes v. Trans World Airlines
column10: Inc.
column12: distinguished.  Petitioners' reliance on the legislative history of citizen suit provisions is also misplaced
column13: since nothing in that history militates against honoring the plain language of the notice requirement.  In fact
column14: requiring citizens to comply with the notice and delay requirements furthers Congress' goal of striking a balance between encouraging citizen suits and avoiding burdening the federal courts with excessive numbers of such suits
column15: since notice allows government agencies and alleged violators to achieve compliance without the need for suit.  Petitioners' assertion that giving effect to the literal meaning of the notice provisions would allow violations to go unchecked during the 60-day waiting period is not persuasive
column16: since this problem results from the balance knowingly struck by Congress in developing the citizen suit provisions
column17: and since it is likely that compliance with the notice requirement will trigger appropriate federal or state enforcement actions to prevent serious damage.  Moreover
column18: it is not irrational to require a citizen to wait 60 days to commence suit after agencies and alleged violators have specifically declined to act in response to notice by the citizen
column19: since a violator or agency may change its mind as the threat of suit becomes imminent.  Pp.  493 U. S. 26-31.

column1: (c) In light of this Court's literal interpretation of the statutory requirement
column2: the question whether  6972(b) is jurisdictional in the strict sense of that term
column3: or is merely procedural
column4: need not be determined.  Requiring dismissal for noncompliance with the notice provision is supported by the EPA
column5: and will further judicial efficiency by relieving courts of the need to make case-by-case determinations of when or whether failure to comply is fatal.   493 U. S.  31-32.

column2: the factors that have led this Court to apply decisions nonretroactively are not present here:  this decision does not establish a new rule of law or overrule clear past precedent on which litigants may have relied
column3: and the statute itself put petitioners on notice of the requirements for bringing suit.  Retroactive operation of this decision will further Congress' purpose of giving agencies and alleged violators a 60-day nonadversarial period to achieve compliance with RCRA regulations.  Moreover
column4: dismissal will not deprive petitioners of their ""right to a day in court
column5: since they remain free to give the statutorily required notice and file their suit.  Pp.  493 U. S. 32-33.

column1: When petitioner Terrell sought postconviction relief in the Ohio courts
column2: they held that he had defaulted his ineffective assistance of counsel claim by failing to raise it on direct appeal
column3: as required by State v. Cole
column5: Ohio had permitted such claims in collateral challenges even if they had not been presented on direct appeal.  Terrell then petitioned for a federal writ of habeas corpus
column6: arguing that the Cole rule postdated his appeal and that he could not have known that he would default his claim if he failed to raise it on direct appeal.  The District Court agreed
column7: finding that Ohio could not invoke its procedural default rule retroactively
column8: but proceeded to deny Terrell's claim on the merits.  The Court of Appeals affirmed on the ground that the District Court properly determined that the ineffective assistance claim was not reviewable because of Terrell's failure to raise it in the state court proceedings.

column1: Held:  The Court of Appeals affirmed a decision that the District Court never made
column2: and so never reviewed that court's actual decision.  The District Court reached the merits of Terrell's claim after it determined that the only applicable default rule postdated his conviction.  However
column3: the Court of Appeals neither noted nor addressed the retroactivity issue.  Review of the procedural bar and retroactivity issues should be undertaken based on a correct formulation of the District Court's ruling.

column7: and that the restrictions on speech were reasonable in light of the dormitories' purpose.  Viewing the challenged application of the resolution as a restriction on commercial speech
column8: and therefore applying the test articulated in Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corp. v. Public Service Comm'n of New York
column10: the Court of Appeals concluded that it was unclear whether the resolution directly advanced the State's asserted interests and whether
column12: it was the least restrictive means to that end.  The court therefore reversed and remanded to the trial court.

column2: Inc. (AFS)
column3: from demonstrating and selling its housewares at a party hosted in a student dormitory

The Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO)
column3: which is Title IX of the Organized Crime Control Act of 1970 (OCCA)
column4: imposes criminal and civil liability upon persons who engage in certain ""prohibited activities
column5: each of which is defined to include
column6: as a necessary element
column7: proof of a ""pattern of racketeering activity
column8: 1962.  ""Racketeering activity"" means ""any act or threat involving"" specified state law crimes
column9: any ""act"" indictable under specified federal statutes
column10: and certain federal ""offenses.""  1961(1).  A ""pattern"" requires ""at least two acts of racketeering activity"" within a 10-year period.   1961(5).  Petitioners
column12: filed a civil action in the District Court against Northwestern Bell and other respondents
column13: including members of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (MPUC) -- which is responsible for determining Northwestern Bell's rates -- seeking an injunction and treble damages.  They raised four separate claims under  1962(a)
column19: Northwestern Bell made various cash and in-kind payments to MPUC members
column20: and thereby influenced them to approve rates for the company in excess of a fair and reasonable amount.  The District Court dismissed the complaint
column21: under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6)
column22: for failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted
column23: on the ground that each of the fraudulent acts alleged was ""committed in furtherance of a single scheme to influence MPUC commissioners
column24: rather than multiple illegal schemes.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column26: a single scheme is insufficient to establish a pattern of racketeering activity.

column1: 1. In order to prove a pattern of racketeering activity
column2: a plaintiff or prosecutor must show at least two racketeering predicates that are related and that amount to
column3: or threaten the likelihood of
column4: continued criminal activity.  Proof of neither relationship nor continuity requires a showing that the racketeering predicates were committed in furtherance of multiple criminal schemes.  Pp.  492 U. S. 236-249.

column1: (a) Section 1961(5) states that at least two racketeering predicates committed within a 10-year period are necessary to establish a RICO

column2: but implies that two acts may not be sufficient.  Section 1961(5) thus assumes that there is something to a pattern beyond merely the number of predicates involved.  In normal usage
column3: the word ""pattern"" would also be taken to require not simply a multiplicity of predicates
column4: but rather predicates arranged or ordered by reason of the relationship they bear to each other or to some external organizing principle.  The text of RICO fails to identify the forms of relationship or external principles to be used to determine whether predicates fall into a pattern.  RICO's legislative history
column5: however
column6: establishes that Congress intended that to prove a ""pattern of racketeering activity
column7: a plaintiff or prosecutor must show both ""relationship"" and ""continuity"" -- that the racketeering predicates are related
column8: and that they either constitute or threaten long-term criminal activity.  Pp.  492 U. S. 237-239.

column1: (b) Relationship and continuity are two distinct requirements
column2: though their proof will often overlap.  RICO's notion of relationship is no more constrained than that used in Title X of OCCA
column3: under which

column1: criminal conduct forms a pattern if it embraces criminal acts that have the same or similar purposes
column2: results
column3: participants
column5: or methods of commission
column6: or otherwise are interrelated by distinguishing characteristics and are not isolated events.""

column1: 18 U.S.C.  3575(e).  Continuity of racketeering activity likewise may be demonstrated in a variety of ways.  Continuity is centrally a temporal concept
column2: and may be either closed- or open-ended.  A party alleging a RICO violation may demonstrate continuity over a closed period by proving a series of related predicates extending over a substantial period of time.  Otherwise
column3: it must be shown that the predicates establish a threat of long-term racketeering activity -- for example
column4: because the predicates themselves involve a distinct threat of such activity; because they are part of the regular way of doing business for an ongoing entity such as a criminal association or legitimate business; or because they are a regular means of conducting or participating in an ongoing RICO enterprise.  Although proof of multiple criminal schemes may be relevant to this inquiry into continuity
column5: it is not the only way to show continuity.  Adopting the Court of Appeals' multiple scheme test would bring a rigidity to the methods of proving a pattern not present in the idea of ""continuity"" itself
column6: and it would introduce a concept -- the ""scheme"" -- that does not appear in RICO's language or legislative history.  Pp.  492 U. S. 239-243.

column1: (c) Neither RICO's language nor its legislative.history supports a rule that a defendant's racketeering activities form a pattern only if they are characteristic of organized crime.  No such restriction appears in RICO's text.  Nor is there any language suggesting that RICO's scope should be limited to acts of an association
column2: rather than an individual acting alone.  Moreover
column3: Congress' approach in RICO can be contrasted with

column1: its decision to enact explicit limitations to organized crime in other statutes.  E.g.
column2: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968
column3: 601(b).  The argument that RICO's broad language should be read restrictively to be congruous with RICO's purpose to eradicate organized crime is rejected:  the legislative history shows Congress had no such restriction in mind.  Pp.  492 U. S. 243-249.

column1: 2. The Court of Appeals erred in affirming the District Court's dismissal of petitioners' complaint for failure to allege facts sufficient to demonstrate a ""pattern of racketeering activity.""  Consistent with the allegations in their complaint
column2: petitioners may be able to prove that the multiple predicates alleged satisfy the requirements of continuity and relationship
column3: and hence satisfy RICO's pattern of racketeering element.  Pp.  492 U. S. 249-250.

column1: Respondents Joseph Kelly and Kelco Disposal
column2: Inc.
column3: filed suit against petitioners (collectively BFI) in Federal District Court
column4: charging BFI with antitrust violations and with interfering with Kelco's contractual relations in violation of Vermont tort law.  A jury found BFI liable on both counts
column5: and awarded Kelco
column6: in addition to $51
column7: 146 in compensatory damages
column8: $6 million in punitive damages on the state law claim.  Denying BFI's post-trial motions
column9: the District Court upheld the jury's punitive damages award.  The Court of Appeals affirmed as to both liability and damages
column10: holding that
column11: even if the Eighth Amendment were applicable
column12: the punitive damages awarded were not so disproportionate as to be constitutionally excessive.

column1: 1. The Excessive Fines Clause of the Eighth Amendment does not apply to punitive damages awards in cases between private parties; it does not constrain such an award when the government neither has prosecuted the action nor has any right to recover a share of the damages awarded.  Pp.  492 U. S. 262-276.
(a) The primary concern which drove the Framers of the Eighth Amendment was the potential for governmental abuse of ""prosecutorial"" power
column2: not concern with the extent or purposes of civil damages.  Nothing in English history suggests that the Excessive Fines Clause of the English Bill of Rights of 1689
column3: the direct ancestor of the Eighth Amendment
column4: was intended to apply to damages awarded in disputes between private parties.  Pp.  492 U. S. 264-268.

column1: (b) The history of the use and abuse in England of amercements
column2: including the fact that Magna Carta placed limits on the Crown's use of excessive amercements
column3: is no basis for concluding that the Excessive Fines Clause limits a civil jury's ability to award punitive damages.  Magna Carta was aimed at putting limits on the excesses of royal power
column4: purposes which are clearly inapposite in a case where a private party receives exemplary damages from another party and the government has no share in the recovery.  Any overlap between civil and criminal procedure at the time of Magna Carta is insignificant when all indications are that English courts never have understood Magna Carta's amercements clauses to be relevant to private damages of any kind.  Pp.  492 U. S. 268-273.

column1: (c) The language of the Excessive Fines Clause and the nature of our constitutional framework make it clear that the Eighth Amendment places limits on the steps a government may take against an individual.  The fact that punitive damages are imposed through the aegis of courts and serve to advance governmental interests in punishment and deterrence is insufficient to support applying the Excessive Fines Clause in a case between private parties.  Here
column2: the government of Vermont has not taken a positive step to punish
column3: as it does in the criminal context
column4: nor used the civil courts to extract large payments or forfeiture for the purpose of raising revenue or disabling some individual.  Pp.  492 U. S. 273-276.

column1: 2. Because BFI failed to raise before either the District Court or the Court of Appeals the question whether the punitive damages award was excessive under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
column2: this Court will not consider the effect of due process on the award.  Pp.  492 U. S. 276-277.

column1: 3. Federal common law does not provide a basis for disturbing the jury's punitive damages award.  In performing the limited function of a federal appellate court
column2: this Court perceives no federal common law standard
column3: or compelling federal policy
column4: that convinces the Court it should not accord considerable deference to a district court's decision not to order a new trial.  The District Court in this case properly instructed the jury on Vermont law and applied the proper state law standard in considering whether the verdict was excessive
column5: and the Court of Appeals correctly held that the District Court did not abuse its discretion.  Pp.  492 U. S. 277-280.

column1: 1. There is no exemption from  853's forfeiture or pretrial restraining order provisions for assets that a defendant wishes to use to retain an attorney.  Pp.  491 U. S. 606-614.

(a) Section 853's language is plain and unambiguous.  Congress could not have chosen stronger words to express its intent that forfeiture be mandatory than  853(a)'s language that upon conviction a person ""shall forfeit . . . any property"" and that the sentencing court ""shall order"" a forfeiture.  Likewise
column2: the statute provides a broad definition of property which does not even hint at the idea that assets used for attorney's fees are not included.  Every Court of Appeals that has finally passed on this argument has agreed with this view.  Neither the Act's legislative history nor legislators' post-enactment statements support respondent's argument that an exception should be created because the statute does not expressly include property to be used for attorney's fees
column3: or because Congress simply did not consider the prospect that forfeiture

column1: would reach such property.  To the contrary
column2: in the Victims of Crime Act -- which requires forfeiture of a convicted defendant's collateral profits derived from his crimes and which was enacted simultaneously with the statute in question -- Congress adopted expressly the precise exemption from forfeiture which respondent is seeking to have implied in  853.  Moreover
column3: respondent's admonition that courts should construe statutes to avoid decision as to their constitutionality is not license for the judiciary to rewrite statutory language.  Pp.  491 U. S. 606-611.

column1: The Education of the Handicapped Act (EHA)-which enacts a comprehensive scheme to assure that handicapped children may achieve a free public education appropriate for their needs-provides
column2: inter alia
column3: that parents may challenge the appropriateness of their child's "" individualized education program"" (IEP) in an administrative hearing with subsequent judicial review. Respondent Muth (hereinafter respondent) requested a hearing to contest the local school district's IEP for his son Alex
column4: who is handicapped within the meaning of the EHA. Before the hearing was convened
column5: respondent enrolled Alex in a private school. Alex's IEP then was revised and declared appropriate by the hearing examiner
column6: and that decision was affirmed by Pennsylvania's secretary of education more than one year after the original hearing. While the administrative proceedings were under way
column7: respondent brought suit in the Federal District Court against the school district and the secretary challenging the appropriateness of the IEP and the validity of the administrative proceedings and seeking
column8: among other things
column9: reimbursement for Alex's private-school tuition and attorney's fees. The court found that
column10: while the revised IEP was appropriate
column11: procedural flaws had delayed the administrative process and that
column12: since the EHA had abrogated the Commonwealth's Eleventh Amendment immunity from suit
column13: the school district and the Commonwealth were jointly and severally liable for reimbursement of Alex's tuition and attorney's fees. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

The question before us is whether the Education of the Handicapped Act abrogates the States' Eleventh Amendment immunity from suit in the federal courts.
The Education of the Handicapped Act (EHA)
column2: 84 Stat. 175
column3: as amended
column4: 20 U.S.C. 1400 et seq. (1982 ed. and Supp. V.)
column5: enacts a comprehensive scheme to assure that handicapped children may receive a free public education appropriate to their needs. To achieve these ends
column6: the Act mandates certain procedural requirements for participating state and local educational agencies. In particular
column7: the Act guarantees to parents the right to participate in the development of an ""individualized education program"" (IEP) for their handicapped child
column8: and to challenge the appropriateness of their child's IEP in an administrative hearing with subsequent judicial review. See 20 U.S.C. 1415 (1982 ed. and Supp. V); School Committee of Burlington v. Department of Education of Massachusetts

column2: the son of respondent Russell Muth (hereinafter respondent )
column3: is a bright child
column4: but one handicapped within the meaning of the EHA by a language learning disability and associated emotional problems. Alex was enrolled in public school in the Central Bucks School District of Pennsylvania from 1980 to 1983. In the summer of 1983
column5: respondent requested a statutory administrative hearing to challenge the district's IEP for Alex. In September
column6: shortly before the hearing convened
column7: respondent enrolled Alex in a private school for learning disabled children for the coming school year.

column1: The hearing examiner found that Alex's original IEP was inappropriate and made a number of recommendations. Both respondent and the school district then appealed the decision to the secretary of education
column2: as provided under Pennsylvania law
column3: see 22 Pa.Code 13.32(24) (1988). The secretary remanded the case to the hearing examiner with in-

column1: structions to the school district to revise Alex's IEP (1988). After the district did so
column2: the hearing examiner issued a decision declaring the revised IEP appropriate
column3: and the secretary affirmed that decision on October 24
column5: more than a year after the original due process hearing.

column1: While the administrative proceedings were underway
column2: respondent brought this suit in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the school district and the state secretary of education
column3: whose successor is petitioner here. As amended
column4: respondent's complaint alleged that the district's IEP for Alex was inappropriate and that the Commonwealth's administrative proceedings had violated the procedural requirements of the EHA in two respects: the assignment of review to the secretary
column5: an allegedly partial officer; and the delays occasioned by the secretary's remand to the hearing examiner. Respondent requested declaratory and injunctive relief
column6: reimbursement for Alex's private-school tuition in 1983- 1984
column7: and attorney's fees.

column1: The District Court found various procedural infirmities in Pennsylvania's administrative scheme and entered summary judgment on respondent's procedural claims. The court held a hearing to resolve the remaining issues in the case and to determine the proper remedy for the procedural violations. The court concluded that
column2: while the district's proposed IEP for 1983-1984 had been appropriate within the meaning of the EHA
column3: respondent was entitle to reimbursement for Alex's tuition that year because the procedural flaws had delayed the administrative process. The District Court further determined that the school district and the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania were jointly and severally liable
column4: agreeing with respondent that the EHA abrogated Pennsylvania's Eleventh Amendment immunity from suit. The court also awarded attorney's fees
column5: assessed jointly and severally against the school district and the Commonwealth.

column1: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed. Muth v. Central Bucks School Dist.

column2: the Court of Appeals agreed with the District Court that the Eleventh Amendment did not bar the reimbursement award against the Commonwealth. The court concluded that "" the text of EHA and its legislative history leave no doubt that Congress intended to abrogate the 11th amendment immunity of the states."" Id.

column1: To resolve a conflict among the Circuits
column2: we granted certiorari
column3: sub nom. Gilhool v. Muth
column5: on the question whether the EHA abrogates the States' sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment. Compare David D. v. Dartmouth School Committee
column6: 775 F.2d 411 (CA1 1985) (finding abrogation)
column7: with Gary A. v. New Trier High School Dist. No. 203
column8: 796 F.2d 940 (CA7 1986); Doe v. Maher
column10: 673 F.2d 969 ( CA8 1982) (finding no abrogation). We now reverse.

column2: acting in the exercise of its enforcement authority under 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment
column3: 1 may abrogate the States' Eleventh Amendment immunity. Fitzpatrick v. Bitzer
column6: 2671 (1976). We have stressed
column7: however
column8: that abrogation of sovereign immunity upsets ""the fundamental constitutional balance between the Federal Government and the States
column13: placing a considerable strain on "" '[t]he principles of federalism that inform Eleventh Amendment doctrine
column14: ' "" Pennhurst State School and Hospital v. Halderman
column22: 2573-2574 (1978). To temper Congress' acknowledged powers of

column1: abrogation with due concern for the Eleventh Amendment's role as an essential component of our constitutional structure
column2: we have applied a simple but stringent test: ""Congress may abrogate the States' constitutionally secured immunity from suit in federal court only by making its intention unmistakably clear in the language of the statute."" Atascadero
column3: supra

column1: In concluding that the EHA contains the requisite clear statement of congressional intent
column2: the Court of Appeals rested principally on three textual provisions. The court first cited the Act's preamble
column3: which states Congress' finding that ""it is in the national interest that the Federal government assist State and local efforts to provide programs to meet the education needs of handicapped children in order to assure equal protection of the law."" 20 U.S.C. 1400(b)(9). Second
column4: and most important for the Court of Appeals
column5: was the Act's judicial review provision
column6: which permits parties aggrieved by the administrative process to ""bring a civil action . . . in any State court of competent jurisdiction or in a district court of the United Stat without regard to the amount in controversy."" 20 U.S.C. 1415(e)(2). Finally
column7: the Court of Appeals pointed to a 1986 amendment to the EHA
column8: which states that the Act's provision for a reduction of attorney's fees shall not apply ""if the court finds that the State or local educational agency unreasonably protracted the final resolution of the action or proceeding or there was a violation of this section."" 20 U.S.C. 1415(e)(4)(G) (1982 ed.
column9: Supp. V ). In the view of the Court of Appeals
column10: this amendment represented an express statement of Congress' understanding that States can be parties in civil actions brought under the EHA.

column1: Respondent supplements these points with some nontextual arguments. Most notably
column2: respondent argues that abrogation is ""necessary . . . to achieve the EHA's goals
column3: Brief for Respondent Muth 37; and that the 1986 amendments to another statute
column5: 100 Stat.

column3: Supp. IV)
column4: expressly abrogate state immunity from suits brought under the EHA
column5: Brief for Respondent Muth 30. In connection with the latter argument
column6: respondent recognizes that the Rehabilitation Act amendments expressly apply only to ""violations that occur in whole or in part after October 21
column8: Supp. IV). Respondent contends
column10: that ""[a]lthough the amendment became effective after Muth initially filed suit

column1: We turn first to respondent's nontextual arguments
column2: because they are the easier to dismiss. It is far from certain that the EHA cannot function if the States retain immunity
column3: or that the 1986 amendments to the Rehabilitation Act are a useful guide to congressional intent in 1975. Indeed
column4: the language of the 1986 amendments to the Rehabilitation Act appears to cut against respondent. Without intending in any way to prejudge the Rehabilitation Act amendments
column5: we note that a comparison of the language in the amendments with the language of the EHA serves only to underscore the difference in the two statutes
column6: and the absence of any clear statement of abrogation in the EHA. The amendments to the Rehabilitation Act read in pertinent part:

column1: ""A State shall not be immune under the Eleventh Amendment of the Constitution of the United States from suit in Federal court for a violation of [several enumerated provisions] or the provisions of any other Federal statute prohibiting discrimination by recipients of

column2: Supp. IV).

column1: When measured against such explicit consideration of abrogation of the Eleventh Amendment
column2: the EHA's treatment of the question appears ambiguous at best.
however
column3: respondent's contentions are beside the point. Our opinion in Atascadero should have left no doubt that we will conclude Congress intended to abrogate sovereign immunity only if its intention is ""unmistakably clear in the language of the statute."" Atascadero
column5: at 242. Lest Atascadero be thought to contain any ambiguity
column6: we reaffirm today that in this area of the law
column7: evidence of congressional intent must be both unequivocal and textual. Respondent's evidence is neither. In particular
column8: we reject the approach of the Court of Appeals
column10: ""[w]hile the text of the federal legislation must bear evidence of such an intention
column11: the legislative history may still be used as a reso rce in determining whether Congress' intention to lift the bar has been made sufficiently manifest."" 839 F.2d
column12: at 128. Legislative history generally will be irrelevant to a judicial inquiry into whether Congress intended to abrogate the Eleventh Amendment. If Congress' intention is ""unmistakably clear in the language of the statute
column13: recourse to legislative history will be unnecessary; if Congress' intention is not unmistakably clear
column14: recourse to legislative history will be futile
column15: because by definition the rule of Atascadero will not be met.

column1: The gist of Justice BRENNAN's argument appears to be that application of the governing law in Atascadero is unfair in this case. The dissent complains that we ""resor[t] to an interpretative standard that Congress could have anticipated only with the aid of a particularly effective crystal ball."" Post
column2: at 241. This complaint appears to be premised on an unrealistic and cynical view of the legislative process. We find it difficult to believe that the 94th Congress
column3: taking careful stock of the state of Eleventh Amendment law

column1: would drop coy hints but stop short of making its intention manifest. Rather
column2: the salient point in our view is that it cannot be said with perfect confidence that Congress in fact intended in 1975 to abrogate sovereign immunity
column3: and imperfect confidence will not suffice given the special constitutional concerns in this area. Cf. Johnson v. Robison
column6: 1168-1169 (1974) ( federal statute will not be construed to preclude judicial review of constitutional challenges absent clear and convincing evidence of congressional intent).

column1: We now turn our attention to the proper focus of an inquiry into congressional abrogation of sovereign immunity
column2: the language of the statute. We cannot agree that the textual provisions on which the Court of Appeals relied
column3: or any other provisions of the EHA
column4: demonstrate with unmistakable clarity that Congress intended to abrogate the States' immunity from suit. The EHA makes no reference whatsoever to either the Eleventh Amendment or the States' sovereign immunity. Cf. supra
column5: at 228. Nor does any provision cited by the Court of Appeals address abrogation in even oblique terms
column6: much less with the clarity Atascadero requires. The general statement of legislative purpose in the Act's preamble simply has nothing to do with the States' sovereign immunity. The 1986 amendment to the EHA deals only with attorney's fees
column7: and does not alter or speak to what parties are subject to suit. Respondent conceded as much at oral argument
column8: acknowledging that ""the 1986 EHA Amendments . . . are not directly relevant [here] because they concerned only attorney's fees."" Tr. of Oral Arg. 28. Finally
column10: the centerpiece of the Court of Appeals' textual analysis
column11: provides judicial review for aggrieved parties
column12: but in no way intimates that the States' sovereign immunity is abrogated. As we made plain in Atascadero: ""A general authorization for suit in federal court is not the kind of unequivocal statutory language sufficient to abrogate the Eleventh Amendment."" 473 U.S.
column13: at 246

column2: respondent's attempt to distinguish this case from Atascadero appears to reduce to the proposition that the EHA ""is replete with references to the states
column3: whereas in ""Atascadero . . . the statutory language at issue did not include mention of states."" Brief for Respondent Muth 32-33. We recognize that the EHA's frequent reference to the States
column4: and its delineation of the States' important role in securing an appropriate education for handicapped children
column5: make the States
column6: along with local agencies
column7: logical defendants in suits alleging violations of the EHA. This statutory structure lends force to the inference that the States were intended to be subject to damages actions for violations of the EHA. But such a permissible inference
column8: whatever ts logical force
column9: would remain just that: a permissible inference. It would not be the unequivocal declaration which
column10: we reaffirm today
column11: is necessary before we will determine that Congress intended to exercise its powers of abrogation.

column1: We hold that the statutory language of the EHA does not evince an unmistakably clear intention to abrogate the States' constitutionally secured immunity from suit. [Footnote 3] The Eleventh Amendment bars respondent's attempt to collect tuition reimbursement from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed
column2: and the case is remanded for proceedings consistent with this opinion.
concurring.

column3: that  1981 prohibits racial discrimination in the making and enforcement of private contracts.  Stare decisis compels the Court to adhere to that interpretation

column6: unlike constitutional interpretation

column9: which has not been undermined by subsequent changes or development in the law
column10: has not proved to be unworkable
column11: and does not pose an obstacle to the realization of objectives embodied in other statutes
column12: particularly Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.  Furthermore
column13: Runyon is entirely consistent with society's deep commitment to the eradication of race-based discrimination.  Pp.  491 U. S. 171-175.

column2: which provides that ""[a]ll persons . . . shall have the same right . . . to make and enforce contracts . . . as is enjoyed by white citizens
column3: because that provision does not apply to conduct which

column1: occurs after the formation of a contract and which does not interfere with the right to enforce established contract obligations.  Pp.  491 U. S. 175-185.
(a) Since  1981 is restricted in its scope to forbidding racial discrimination in the ""mak[ing] and enforce[ment]"" of contracts
column2: it cannot be construed as a general proscription of discrimination in all aspects of contract relations.  It provides no relief where an alleged discriminatory act does not involve the impairment of one of the specified rights.  The ""right . . . to make . . . contracts"" extends only to the formation of a contract
column3: such that  1981's prohibition encompasses the discriminatory refusal to enter into a contract with someone
column4: as well as the offer to make a contract only on discriminatory terms.  That right does not extend to conduct by the employer after the contract relation has been established
column5: including breach of the contract's terms or the imposition of discriminatory working conditions.  The ""right . . . to . . . enforce contracts"" embraces only protection of a judicial or nonjudicial legal process
column6: and of a right of access to that process
column7: that will address and resolve contract law claims without regard to race.  It does not extend beyond conduct by an employer which impairs an employee's ability to enforce through legal process his or her established contract rights.  Pp.  491 U. S. 176-178.

column6: subjected her to a racial slur

column1: The Education of the Handicapped Act (EHA) -- which enacts a comprehensive scheme to assure that handicapped children may achieve a free public education appropriate for their needs -- provides
column2: inter alia
column3: that parents may challenge the appropriateness of their child's ""individualized education program"" (IEP) in an administrative hearing with subsequent judicial review.  Respondent Muth (hereinafter respondent) requested a hearing to contest the local school district's IEP for his son Alex
column4: who is handicapped within the meaning of the EHA.  Before the hearing was convened
column5: respondent enrolled Alex in a private school.  Alex's IEP then was revised and declared appropriate by the hearing examiner
column6: and that decision was affirmed by Pennsylvania's secretary of education more than one year after the original hearing.  While the administrative proceedings were underway
column7: respondent brought suit in the Federal District Court against the school district and the secretary challenging the appropriateness of the IEP and the validity of the administrative proceedings and seeking
column8: among other things
column9: reimbursement for Alex's private school tuition and attorney's fees.  The court found that

column1: Appellant Carella was convicted by a California jury of grand theft for failure to return a rented car.  At his trial
column2: the judge instructed the jury that a person ""shall be presumed to have embezzled"" a vehicle if it is not returned within 5 days of the rental agreement's expiration date
column3: and that ""intent to commit theft by fraud is presumed"" from failure to return the property within 20 days of demand.  The Appellate Department held these presumptions valid
column4: even though the prosecution acknowledged that the instructions imposed conclusive presumptions as to core elements of the crime in violation of the Due Process Clause.

column1: Held:  The jury instructions violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  The instructions were mandatory
column2: since they could have been understood by reasonable jurors to require them to find the presumed facts if the State proved certain predicate facts.  Thus
column3: they directly foreclosed independent jury consideration of whether the facts proved established certain elements of the offenses with which Carella was charged
column4: and relieved the State of its burden
column5: under In re Winship
column7: of proving by evidence every essential element of Carella's crime beyond a reasonable doubt.  The determination whether the error was harmless is for the lower court to make in the first instance.

column1: Black individuals and a branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People brought actions in Federal District Court against the city of Birmingham
column2: Alabama
column3: and the Jefferson County Personnel Board (Board)
column4: alleging that the defendants had engaged in racially discriminatory hiring and promotion practices in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and other federal law.  Consent decrees were eventually entered that included goals for hiring blacks as firefighters and for promoting them.  Respondent white firefighters subsequently brought suit in the District Court against the city and the Board
column5: alleging that
column6: because of their race
column7: they were being denied promotions in favor of less qualified blacks in violation of federal law.  They argued that the city and the Board were making promotion decisions on the basis of race in reliance on the consent decrees
column8: and that those decisions constituted impermissible racial discrimination.  After trial
column9: the District Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.  It held that respondents were precluded from challenging employment decisions taken pursuant to the consent decrees
column10: even though they had not been parties to the proceedings in which the decrees were entered.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column11: rejecting the ""impermissible collateral attack"" doctrine that immunizes parties to a consent decree from discrimination charges by nonparties for actions taken pursuant to the decree.

column1: Title 28 U.S.C.  1332 confers diversity jurisdiction in the district courts when a citizen of one State sues both aliens and citizens of a State different from the plaintiff's
column3: and when a citizen of a State sues aliens only
column5: an Illinois corporation
column6: invoking jurisdiction under  1332(a)(3)
column7: brought a state law contract action in the District Court against a Venezuelan corporation and
column8: as joint and several guarantors of royalty payments due under the agreement
column9: four Venezuelan citizens and one Bettison
column10: a United States citizen domiciled in Venezuela.  After several years of litigation
column13: granted partial summary judgment for the guarantors.  A Court of Appeals panel found that Bettison's status as a United States citizen not domiciled within a State destroyed  1332(a)(3) jurisdiction
column14: but granted petitioner's motion to dismiss him from the suit
column15: thereby producing complete diversity under  1332(a)(2).  The court then decided the merits.  The Court of Appeals en banc reversed
column16: concluding that neither 28 U.S.C.  1653 -- which provides that ""[d]efective allegations of jurisdiction may be amended . . . in the trial or appellate courts"" -- nor Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 21 -- which provides that a court may add or drop parties at any stage of the action on such terms as are just -- empowers appellate courts to dismiss a dispensable party who spoils statutory diversity jurisdiction.  However
column17: recognizing that Rule 21 permits district courts to drop dispensable nondiverse parties
column18: the court remanded the case to the District Court for a determination whether it would be prudent to drop Bettison from the litigation.

column1: Held:  A court of appeals has the authority to grant a motion to dismiss a dispensable nondiverse party
column2: and need not remand the case to the district court for dismissal in that court's discretion.  Pp.  490 U. S. 830-838.

column1: (a) Since  1653 speaks of amending jurisdictional allegations
column2: it would apply if petitioner had made an incorrect statement about jurisdiction that actually existed
column3: but it does not apply where
column5: there are defects in the jurisdictional facts themselves.  This interpretation is consistent with  1653's legislative history and the language of its predecessor statute
column6: as well as the view of every Court of Appeals that has considered  1653's scope.  Pp.  490 U. S. 830-832.

column1: (b) Virtually every modern Court of Appeals faced with this issue has concluded that it has the authority to dismiss a dispensable nondiverse party by virtue of Rule 21.  Furthermore
column2: this Court has exercised similar authority both under Rule 21
column3: see Mullaney v. Anderson
column5: and prior to the enactment of the Federal Rules.  See Carneal v. Banks
column6: 10 Wheat. 181.  Other early appellate courts relied for their authority to dismiss a nondiverse party on  32 of the Judiciary Act of 1789 or on the courts' own inherent powers.  This Court declines to disturb that deeply rooted understanding of appellate power
column7: particularly when requiring dismissal of the suit after years of litigation would impose unnecessary and wasteful burdens on the parties
column8: judges
column9: and other litigants awaiting judicial attention.  Here
column10: the practicalities weigh heavily in favor of the decision to dismiss Bettison since
column12: petitioner would be compelled to refile in the District Court against the diverse parties and proceed to a preordained judgment merely for the sake of a hypertechnical jurisdictional purity.  Although an appellate court should exercise its authority sparingly
column13: carefully considering whether dismissal of the nondiverse party will prejudice any of the other parties and remanding to the district court when appropriate
column14: this Court declines to erect a per se rule that the district court must first make such a determination in every case.  Here
column15: none of the parties will be harmed by Bettison's dismissal
column16: since his presence did not provide petitioner with a tactical advantage; since he was not indispensable to the suit; and since any possible prejudice to him personally was eliminated when the Court of Appeals panel terminated the litigation against him with prejudice. column4: but made no specific claim of prejudice.  The Court of Appeals affirmed their convictions

column6: as well as ""such additional duties as are not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States.""  The court held that Congress intended this additional duties clause to be construed broadly enough to include jury selection by magistrates
column7: adding that such a designation does not violate Article III or the Due Process Clause.

column1: Jobs at petitioners' Alaskan salmon canneries are of two general types:  unskilled ""cannery jobs"" on the cannery lines
column2: which are filled predominantly by nonwhites; and ""noncannery jobs
column3: most of which are classified as skilled positions and filled predominantly with white workers
column4: and virtually all of which pay more than cannery positions.  Respondents
column5: a class of nonwhite cannery workers at petitioners' facilities
column6: filed suit in the District Court under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964
column7: alleging
column8: inter alia
column9: that various of petitioners' hiring/promotion practices were responsible for the workforce's racial stratification and had denied them employment as noncannery workers on the basis of race.  The District Court rejected respondents' claims
column10: finding
column12: that nonwhite workers were overrepresented in cannery jobs because many of those jobs were filled under a hiring hall agreement with a predominantly nonwhite union.  The Court of Appeals ultimately reversed in pertinent part
column13: holding
column15: that respondents had made out a prima facie case of disparate impact in hiring for both skilled and unskilled noncannery jobs
column16: relying solely on respondents' statistics showing a high percentage of nonwhite workers in cannery jobs and a low percentage of such workers in noncannery positions.  The court also concluded that
column17: once a plaintiff class has shown disparate impact caused by specific
column19: the burden shifts to the employer to prove the challenged practice's business necessity.

column1: 1. The Court of Appeals erred in ruling that a comparison of the percentage of cannery workers who are nonwhite and the percentage of noncannery workers who are nonwhite makes out a prima facie disparate impact case.  Rather
column2: the proper comparison is generally between the racial composition of the at-issue jobs and the racial composition of the qualified population in the relevant labor market.  Hazelwood School Dist. v. United States
column4: 433 U. S. 308.  With respect to the skilled noncannery jobs at issue
column5: the cannery workforce in no way reflected the pool of job applicants or the qualified labor force population.  Petitioners' selection methods or employment practices cannot be said to have had a disparate impact on nonwhites if

column1: the absence of minorities holding such skilled jobs reflects a dearth of qualified nonwhite applicants for reasons that are not petitioners' fault.  With respect to the unskilled noncannery jobs
column2: as long as there are no barriers or practices deterring qualified nonwhites from applying

The Church of Scientology (Church) provides ""auditing"" sessions designed to increase members' spiritual awareness and training courses at which participants study the tenets of the faith and seek to attain the qualifications necessary to conduct auditing sessions.  Pursuant to a central tenet known as the ""doctrine of exchange
column2: the Church has set forth schedules of mandatory fixed prices for auditing and training sessions which vary according to a session's length and level of sophistication
column3: and which are paid to branch churches.  Under  170 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954
column4: petitioners each sought to deduct such payments on their federal income tax returns as a ""charitable contribution
column5: which is defined as a ""contribution or gift"" to eligible donees.  After respondent Commissioner of Internal Revenue (Commissioner or IRS) disallowed these deductions on the ground that the payments were not ""charitable contributions
column6: petitioners sought review in the Tax Court.  That court upheld the Commissioner's decisions and rejected petitioners' constitutional challenges based on the Establishment and Free Exercise Clauses of the First Amendment.  The Courts of Appeals affirmed on petitioners' separate appeals.

column7: 4044 (a)(5); and finally ""all other benefits under the plan.""   4044(a)(6).  Any remaining funds may be recouped by the employer.   4044(d)(1)(A).  Respondents
column8: five employees of the Lynchburg Foundry Company (Foundry)
column9: formerly a wholly owned subsidiary of petitioner Mead Corp. (Mead)

column1: Petitioner Hildwin was convicted of first-degree murder by a Florida jury.  Since this crime is punishable by death or life imprisonment
column2: state law requires that a separate sentencing proceeding be conducted
column3: in which a jury makes an advisory recommendation but the court makes the ultimate decision whether to impose a death sentence
column4: which it may impose after finding at least one aggravating factor.  The court must make written findings to support its imposition of a death sentence.  In Hildwin's case
column5: the jury rendered a unanimous advisory sentence of death
column6: and the judge imposed the death sentence
column7: finding four aggravating circumstances and nothing in mitigation.  The State Supreme Court affirmed the sentence
column8: rejecting Hildwin's argument that the sentencing scheme violates the Sixth Amendment because it permits the imposition of death without a specific finding by the jury that sufficient aggravating circumstances exist to qualify the defendant for capital punishment.

column1: Held: The Sixth Amendment does not require that the specific findings authorizing the imposition of the death sentence be made by a jury.  Since the Court has held that the Amendment permits a judge to impose a death sentence when the jury recommends life imprisonment
column2: Spaziano v. Florida
column4: it follows that the Amendment does not forbid the judge to make written findings authorizing the imposition of a death sentence when the jury unanimously makes such a recommendation.  There is no Sixth Amendment right to jury sentencing
column5: even where the sentence turns upon specific aggravating circumstances.  McMillan v. Pennsylvania
column6: 477 U. S. 79.  The existence of an aggravating factor is not an element of the offense
column7: but is a sentencing factor that comes into play only after a defendant has been found guilty.

column2: affirmed.

column1: Respondents -- passengers and representatives of the estates of passengers on a cruise ship hijacked by terrorists -- filed suit in the District Court against petitioner
column2: the ship's owner
column3: to recover damages for personal injuries and for the wrongful death of one passenger.  Before trial
column4: petitioner moved to dismiss the actions
column5: citing the forum-selection clause printed on each passenger ticket
column6: which purported to obligate passengers to institute any suit in connection with the contract in Italy and to renounce the right to sue elsewhere.  The District Court denied the motions
column7: holding that the ticket did not give passengers reasonable notice that they were waiving the opportunity to sue in a domestic forum.  The Court of Appeals dismissed petitioner's appeal on the ground that the District Court's dismissal orders were interlocutory
column8: and not appealable under 28 U.S.C.  1291
column9: holding that the orders did not fall within the exception to the rule of nonappealability carved out by the collateral order doctrine.

column1: Held:  An interlocutory order denying a defendant's motion to dismiss a damages action on the basis of a contractual forum-selection clause is not immediately appealable under  1291.  Such an order is not final in the usual sense
column2: for it does not end the litigation on the merits but
column3: on the contrary
column4: ensures that the litigation will continue.  Nor does the order fall within the narrow exception to the normal application of the final judgment rule known as the collateral order doctrine
column5: for the order is not effectively unreviewable on appeal from final judgment.  The right to be sued only in a particular forum
column6: as compared to the right to avoid suit altogether
column7: although not perfectly secured by an appeal after final judgment
column8: is sufficiently vindicable at that stage and is not essentially destroyed if vindication is postponed until trial is completed.  Moreover
column9: the costs associated with unnecessary litigation
column10: should it eventually be decided that the District Court erred in trying the case
column11: do not warrant allowing an immediate appeal of a pretrial order.  That there may be a policy favoring enforcement of foreign forum-selection clauses goes to the merits of petitioner's claim that its ticket agreement requires that suit be filed in Italy and that the agreement should be enforced by the federal courts
column12: but does not affect the appealability of a prejudgment

column2: which turns on the contours of the right asserted
column3: not on the likelihood of eventual success on the merits.

column2: affirmed.
J.

column5: filed a concurring opinion.

column1: |490 u.s. 504|"Green v. Bock Laundry Machine Co.
In petitioner Green's product liability action against respondent Bock
column2: the manufacturer of a machine that injured Green
column3: Bock impeached Green's testimony by eliciting admissions that he had previously been convicted of burglary and a related felony.  After the jury returned a verdict for Bock
column4: Green argued on appeal that the District Court had erred by denying his pretrial motion to exclude the impeaching evidence.  The Court of Appeals summarily affirmed the District Court's ruling
column5: following Circuit precedent established in Diggs v. Lyons
column6: 741 F.2d 577.  Diggs held
column7: inter alia
column8: that Rule 609(a)(1) of the Federal Rules of Evidence -- which specifies that evidence that a witness has been convicted of a felony ""shall"" be admitted for the purpose of attacking the witness' credibility ""only if"" the court determines that the probativeness of the evidence outweighs its prejudice ""to the defendant"" -- mandates admission for impeachment purposes of a civil plaintiff's prior felony convictions
column9: and that the Rule's specific command forecloses the judicial exercise of discretion under Rule 403
column10: which authorizes the exclusion of relevant evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.

column1: Held:  Rule 609(a)(1) requires a judge to permit impeachment of a civil witness with evidence of prior felony convictions regardless of ensuant unfair prejudice to the witness or the party offering the testimony.  Thus
column2: the District Court did not err in allowing the jury to learn through impeaching cross-examination that Green was a convicted felon.  Pp.  490 U. S. 509-527.

column1: (a) The Rule's text is ambiguous with respect to its applicability in civil cases.  By using the restrictive phrase ""to the defendant
column2: the Rule's plain language appears not only to command the weighing of prejudice to a civil defendant
column3: but also to compel the automatic admissibility of prior felony conviction evidence detrimental to a civil plaintiff.  An interpretation that would deny a civil plaintiff the same right to impeach an adversary's testimony that it grants a civil defendant is unacceptable; therefore
column4: the Rule cannot mean what it says as far as civil trials are concerned.  Pp.  490 U. S. 509-511.

column1: (b) The history leading to enactment of the Rule as law establishes that Congress intended that only the accused in a criminal case should be
protected from unfair prejudice by the balancing requirement set out in Rule 609(a)(1).  Pp.  490 U. S. 511-524.
(c) Rule 609(a)(1)'s exclusion of civil witnesses from its weighing language is a specific and mandatory command that impeachment of such witnesses be admitted into evidence
column2: which command overrides a judge's general discretionary authority under Rule 403 to balance probative value against prejudice.  Pp.  490 U. S. 524-526.
affirmed.

column2: the District Court did not err in allowing the jury to learn through impeaching cross-examination that Green was a convicted felon.  Pp.  490 U. S. 509-527.

column1: (a) The Rule's text is ambiguous with respect to its applicability in civil cases.  By using the restrictive phrase ""to the defendant
column2: the Rule's plain language appears not only to command the weighing of prejudice to a civil defendant
column3: but also to compel the automatic admissibility of prior felony conviction evidence detrimental to a civil plaintiff.  An interpretation that would deny a civil plaintiff the same right to impeach an adversary's testimony that it grants a civil defendant is unacceptable; therefore
column4: the Rule cannot mean what it says as far as civil trials are concerned.  Pp.  490 U. S. 509-511.

column1: (b) The history leading to enactment of the Rule as law establishes that Congress intended that only the accused in a criminal case should be

column3: claiming that the Federal Aviation Administration had been negligent in its operation and maintenance of runway lights and in its performance of air traffic control functions. The District Court granted the motion and asserted ""pendent"" jurisdiction under Mine Workers v. Gibbs
column5: concluding that ""judicial economy and efficiency"" favored trying the actions together
column6: and that the claims arose ""from a common nucleus of operative facts.""  The Court of Appeals reversed on interlocutory appeal
column7: categorically rejecting pendent-party jurisdiction under the FTCA.

column6: and Owen Equipment & Erection Co. v. Kroger

column9: even if consideration of the additional claims would promote ""judicial economy and efficiency

column12: the 1948 revision of the Judicial Code
column13: which changed the relevant language of the FTCA from ""any claim against the United States"" to its present form
column14: does not suggest an affirmative grant of pendent party jurisdiction
column15: but is more naturally understood as a stylistic

column7: a city police officer

column15: alleging that they had used excessive force in making the stop
column16: in violation of ""rights secured to him under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution and 42 U.S.C.  1983.""  The District Court granted respondents' motion for a directed verdict at the close of Graham's evidence
column17: applying a four-factor test for determining when excessive use of force gives rise to a  1983 cause of action
column20: whether the force was applied in a good faith effort to maintain and restore discipline or maliciously and sadistically for the very purpose of causing harm.  Johnson v. Glick
column21: 481 F.2d 1028.  The Court of Appeals affirmed

column23: rejecting Graham's argument that it was error to require him to prove that the allegedly excessive force was applied maliciously and sadistically to cause harm

column1: Held:  All claims that law enforcement officials have used excessive force -- deadly or not -- in the course of an arrest
column2: investigatory stop
column3: or other ""seizure"" of a free citizen are properly analyzed under the Fourth Amendment's ""objective reasonableness"" standard
column4: rather than under a substantive due process standard.  Pp.  490 U. S. 392-399.

column1: (a) The notion that all excessive force claims brought under  1983 are governed by a single generic standard is rejected.  Instead
column2: courts must identify the specific constitutional right allegedly infringed by the challenged application of force
column3: and then judge the claim by reference to the specific constitutional standard which governs that right.  Pp.  490 U. S. 393-394.

column1: (b) Claims that law enforcement officials have used excessive force in the course of an arrest
column2: investigatory stop
column3: or other ""seizure"" of a free citizen are most properly characterized as invoking the protections of the Fourth Amendment
column4: which guarantees citizens the right ""to be secure in their persons . . . against unreasonable seizures
column5: and must be judged by reference to the Fourth Amendment's ""reasonableness"" standard.  Pp.  490 U. S. 394-395.

column1: (c) The Fourth Amendment ""reasonableness"" inquiry is whether the officers' actions are ""objectively reasonable"" in light of the facts and circumstances confronting them
column2: without regard to their underlying intent or motivation.  The ""reasonableness"" of a particular use of force must be judged from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene
column3: and its calculus must embody an allowance for the fact that police officers are often forced to make split-second decisions about the amount of force necessary in a particular situation.  Pp.  490 U. S. 396-397.

column1: (d) The Johnson v. Glick test applied by the courts below is incompatible with a proper Fourth Amendment analysis.  The suggestion that the test's ""malicious and sadistic"" inquiry is merely another way of describing conduct that is objectively unreasonable under the circumstances is rejected.  Also rejected is the conclusion that
column2: because individual officers' subjective motivations are of central importance in deciding whether force used against a convicted prisoner violates the Eighth Amendment
column3: it cannot be reversible error to inquire into them in deciding whether force used against a suspect or arrestee violates the Fourth Amendment.  The Eighth Amendment terms ""cruel"" and ""punishment"" clearly suggest some inquiry into subjective state of mind
column4: whereas the Fourth Amendment term ""unreasonable"" does not.  Moreover
column5: the less protective Eighth Amendment standard applies only after the State has complied with the constitutional guarantees traditionally associated with criminal prosecutions.  Pp.  490 U. S. 397-399.

column1: |490 u.s. 296|"Mallard v. United States District Court

column2: an attorney recently admitted to practice before the District Court
column3: was selected to represent indigent inmates in their suit in that court against prison officials under 42 U.S.C.  1983.  After a Magistrate denied his motion to withdraw
column4: he appealed to the District Court
column5: contending that forcing him to represent indigent inmates in a complex action requiring trial skills he did not possess would compel him to violate his ethical obligation to take on only those cases he could handle competently and would exceed the court's authority under 28 U.S.C.  1915(d)
column6: which provides that federal courts may ""request"" an attorney to represent any person claiming in forma pauperis status.  The court upheld the Magistrate's decision
column7: ruling
column8: inter alia
column9: that  1915(d) empowers federal courts to make compulsory appointments in civil actions.  The Court of Appeals denied without opinion Mallard's petition for a writ of mandamus to compel the District Court to allow his withdrawal.

column1: 1. Section 1915(d) does not authorize a federal court to require an unwilling attorney to represent an indigent litigant in a civil case.  The section's operative term is ""request
column2: which bespeaks an intent not to authorize mandatory appointments of counsel.  The fact that  1915(c) -- which was adopted at the same time as  1915(d) -- imposes mandatory duties on court officers and witnesses in in forma pauperis cases demonstrates that Congress knew how to require service when it deemed compulsory service appropriate.  The conclusion that  1915(d) evinces a desire to permit attorneys to decline representation of indigent litigants if in their view their personal
column3: professional
column4: or ethical concerns bid them do so is bolstered by the fact that Congress
column5: when it passed  1915(d) in 1892
column6: was aware of
column7: but chose not to replicate
column8: the language of various state statutes providing for the ""appointment"" or ""assignment"" of counsel in in forma pauperis proceedings; by the fact that no reported pre-1892 American or English decision held that a lawyer could be sanctioned for declining representation without compensation; and by the fact that other pre- and post-1892 federal statutes providing for court-ordered representation specify that the court could ""assign"" or ""appoint"" attorneys

column1: rather than merely ""request"" that they serve.  Contrary to respondent's assertion
column2: construing  1915(d) to allow courts to ask but not compel lawyers to represent indigent litigants does not render the section a nullity on the theory that statutory authorization is unnecessary for a court simply to ask
column3: since the section may meaningfully be read to legitimize a court's request
column4: and therefore to confront a lawyer with an important ethical decision.  Pp.  490 U. S. 300-308.

column1: 2. Mallard discharged his burden of proving that he was entitled to a writ of mandamus
column2: and the Court of Appeals erred when it denied his application.  In resting its decision solely on  1915(d)
column3: the District Court plainly acted beyond its ""jurisdiction.""  In addition
column4: Mallard had no alternative remedy available to him.  Moreover
column5: the principal reasons for this Court's reluctance to condone use of the writ -- the undesirability of making a district court judge a litigant and the inefficiency of piecemeal appellate litigation -- are not present here.  Pp.  490 U. S. 308-310.

column1: 3. Respondents' contention that the federal courts possess inherent authority to require lawyers to serve will not be considered by this Court
column2: since the lower courts did not invoke such authority in reaching their decisions.  P.  490 U. S. 310.
