In an attempt to alleviate a financial crisis plaguing petitioner local union (Local)
column2: which is an affiliate of petitioner international union (International)
column3: the International's president appointed Richard Hawkins as trustee to supervise the Local's affairs
column4: with authority under the International's constitution to suspend the Local's officers and business representatives.  Five days after a special meeting at which the Local's membership defeated Hawkins' proposal to increase their dues
column5: Hawkins notified respondent Lynn
column6: an elected business representative of the Local
column7: that he was being removed ""indefinitely"" from his position because of his outspoken opposition to the proposal at the meeting.  After exhausting his intraunion remedies
column8: Lynn brought suit in Federal District Court
column9: claiming that his removal violated the free speech provision of Title I of the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 (LMRDA or Act).  The court granted summary judgment for petitioners under Finnegan v. Leu
column11: which held that the discharge of a union's appointed business agents by the union president
column12: following his election over the incumbent for whom the business agents had campaigned
column13: did not violate Title I.  However
column15: holding that Finnegan did not control where the dismissed union official was elected
column17: and rejecting the contention that Lynn's removal was valid because it was carried out under Hawkins' authority as trustee.

column1: Held:  The removal of an elected business agent
column2: in retaliation for statements he made at a union meeting in opposition to a dues increase sought by the union trustee
column3: violates the LMRDA.  Pp.  488 U. S. 352-359.

column1: (a) Petitioners' argument is unpersuasive that Lynn's status as an elected
column2: rather than an appointed
column3: official is immaterial
column4: and that the loss of his union employment cannot amount to a Title I violation because he remains a member of the Local and was not prevented from attending the special meeting
column5: expressing his views on the dues proposal
column6: or casting his vote.  Even though Lynn was not actually prevented from exercising such Title I rights
column7: his removal interfered with those rights by forcing him to chose between them and his job.  Moreover
column8: in contrast to the discharge of an appointed union official

column1: official denies the members who voted for him the representative of their choice
column2: and has a more pronounced chilling effect upon their exercise of their own Title I rights
column3: thereby contravening the LMRDA's basic objective of ensuring that unions are democratically governed and responsive to the will of the membership
column4: which must be free to discuss union policies and criticize the leadership without fear of reprisal.  Finnegan
column5: supra
column6: distinguished.

column1: (b) The cause of action of an elected union official removed for exercising his Title I rights is not affected by the fact that the removal is carried out during a trusteeship lawfully imposed under Title III of the Act.  Nothing in the LMRDA's language or legislative history suggests that Title I rights are lost whenever a trusteeship is imposed.  Given this congressional silence
column2: a trustee's Title III authority ordinarily should be construed in a manner consistent with Title I's protections.  As petitioners concede
column3: the imposition of a trusteeship does not destroy the critical right to vote on dues increases which Title I guarantees to local union members.  That right would not be meaningful if a trustee were able to control the members' debate over the issue.  In the instant case
column4: Lynn's statements concerning the proposed dues increase were entitled to protection
column5: since nothing in the International's constitution suggests that the imposition of the trusteeship changed the nature of his office so that he was obligated to support Hawkins' positions.  Pp.  488 U. S. 356-358.

column1: Held:  Section 101(a)(2) claims are governed by state general or residual personal injury statutes of limitations.  Pp.  488 U. S. 323-334.

(a) The well-established general rule requires that the most closely analogous state statute of limitations be borrowed for a federal cause of action not supplied by Congress with its own limitations period.  However
column2: a narrow exception to that rule requires the application of a statute of limitations from elsewhere in federal law when the analogous state statute will frustrate or significantly interfere with federal policies
column3: the federal law clearly provides a closer analogy
column4: and the federal policies at stake and the practicalities of litigation render the federal rule significantly more appropriate.  Pp.  488 U. S. 323-325.

column1: (b) The general borrowing rule requires that state general or residual personal injury statutes of limitations be applied to  101(a)(2) suits.  As a preliminary matter
column2: it must be concluded that all such suits should be characterized in the same way
column3: since the diversion of resources to collateral statute of limitations litigation would interfere with  101(a)(2)'s core purpose of enhancing union democracy by protecting union members' rights to free speech and assembly from incursion by union leadership.  Because  101(a)(2) is modeled on the First Amendment

column4: which also protects the exercise of First Amendment rights
column5: are governed by state general or residual personal injury statutes of limitations.  Moreover
column6: since such state limitations periods are of sufficient length to accommodate the practical difficulties faced by  101(a)(2) plaintiffs -- which include identifying the injury
column7: deciding in the first place to sue and thereby to antagonize union leadership
column8: and finding an attorney -- the practicalities of litigation do not require a search for a more analogous statute of limitations.  Pp.  488 U. S. 325-327.

column1: (c) The narrow exception to the general borrowing rule does not require the adoption of the  10(b) limitations period for  101(a)(2) claims.  Respondents' argument to the contrary fails to take seriously the requirement that analogous state statutes of limitations are to be used unless they frustrate or significantly interfere with federal policies.  The 6-month  10(b) statute of limitations was crafted to accommodate federal interests in stable bargaining relationships between employers and unions and in private dispute resolution under collective bargaining agreements.  Insofar as those interests are implicated by  101(a)(2) claims
column2: however
column3: the relationship will generally be tangential or remote -- as in the present case
column4: which involves an internal union dispute that can have only an indirect impact on economic relations between union and employer and on labor peace.  More importantly
column5: the core federal interest furthered by  101(a)(2) -- the interest in union democracy promoted by union members' free speech and assembly rights -- simply had no part in the design of the  10(b) statute of limitations for unfair labor practice charges.  Indeed
column6: Title I of the LMRDA was a response to a perception that the NLRA
column7: including its unfair labor practices provisions
column8: had failed to provide the necessary protections for free speech and other union members' rights.  Hence
column9: it is not the case here that the federal policies at stake in  101(a)(2) actions make  10(b) significantly more appropriate than the analogous state statutes of limitations that the established borrowing rule favors.  DelCostello

column1: At the conclusion of petitioner's direct testimony in his state court trial for murder and related offenses
column2: the trial judge declared a 15-minute recess and ordered that petitioner not be allowed to talk to anyone
column3: including his lawyer
column4: during the break.  In affirming petitioner's conviction
column5: the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that Geders v. United States
column6: 425 U. S. 80 -- in which it was held that a trial court's order directing a defendant not to consult his attorney during an overnight recess
column7: called while the defendant was on the witness stand
column8: violated his Sixth Amendment right to the assistance of counsel -- did not require reversal
column9: since this Court had there emphasized the fact that a defendant would ""normally confer"" with counsel during an overnight recess
column10: and had explicitly disclaimed any intent to deal with limitations imposed in other circumstances.  The state court declared that
column12: counsel is not permitted to confer with his client between direct and cross-examination.  Subsequently
column13: the Federal District Court granted petitioner a writ of habeas corpus
column14: but the Court of Appeals reversed.  Although agreeing with the District Court that Geders applied
column15: and that constitutional error had occurred
column16: the court disagreed with the lower court's ruling that a defendant subjected to a Geders violation need not demonstrate prejudice in order to have his conviction set aside.  The court concluded that petitioner's conviction should stand because the trial court's error was not prejudicial under Strickland v. Washington
column18: in that the evidence against petitioner was overwhelming
column19: and there was no basis for believing that his testimony on cross-examination would have been different had he been given an opportunity to confer with his counsel during the recess.

column1: 1. A showing of prejudice is not an essential component of a violation of the Geders rule
column2: in light of the fundamental importance of the criminal defendant's constitutional right to be represented by counsel.  By citing Geders in distinguishing between direct governmental interference with that right and denial of the right by virtue of counsel's ineffective assistance
column3: Strickland made clear that the complete denial of the right by the government is not subject to the kind of prejudice analysis that is appropriate

column1: in determining whether the quality of a lawyer's performance itself has been constitutionally ineffective.  Pp.  488 U. S. 278-280.

column2: the Federal Constitution does not compel a trial judge to allow a criminal defendant to confer with his attorney during a brief break in his testimony.  It is an empirical predicate of our system of justice that
column3: quite apart from any question of unethical ""coaching
column5: whether the defendant or a nondefendant
column6: following direct examination is more likely to lead to the discovery of truth than is cross-examination of a witness given time to pause and consult with his lawyer.  Thus
column7: although it may be appropriate to permit such consultation in individual cases
column8: the trial judge must nevertheless be allowed the discretion to maintain the status quo during a brief recess in which there is a virtual certainty that any conversation between the witness and his lawyer would relate exclusively to his ongoing testimony.  The long interruption in Geders was of a different character
column9: because the normal consultation between attorney and client that occurs during an overnight recess would encompass matters that the defendant does have a constitutional right to discuss with his lawyer -- such as the availability of other witnesses
column10: trial tactics
column11: or even the possibility of negotiating a plea bargain -- and the fact that such discussions will inevitably include some consideration of the defendant's ongoing testimony does not compromise that basic right in that instance.  Pp.  488 U. S. 280-285.

column2: petitioner's attorney sought disclosure of evidence seized by investigators from her mobile home-in particular
